content: I find this really sad. Google Books was (and still is) genuinely ambitious, to an almost comical degree. Digitize humanity’s entire corpus of written literature? That’s amazing! Also, good luck. But there’s something to be said for a commercial giant doing this because it thinks there’s something in it for them. Google is unlikely to stop existing any time soon, whereas nonprofits can and often do have money problems, and Google is highly capable of monetizing that data through machine learning and artificial intelligence in a way that few others are. My favorite thing about Google Books is the romantic nature of it. There are so many books that may never be read by another human being simply due to physical scarcity — digitizing them makes niche and unique information widespread and easily discoverable. I’d rather not lose humanities tremendous written body of work, and Google’s as good as any to do it. Though it would be cool if the Library of Congress stepped up it’s game, because, you know, this is the thing they’re supposed to be doing.
